user_query: Using a cash account can someone trade all day on it?
alpaca-7b_response: No, using a cash account does not mean someone can trade all day on it. A cash account is a type of brokerage account where trades settle in three business days, meaning that the funds from the trade will not be available for trading until then. This rule does not prevent day trading, as a trader has all the information they need regarding the cash amounts that will hit their account three business days later. In a cash account, cash postings that arise from trading are treated as unsettled (for three days), but this does not mean that these funds are available for further trading. If someone has $25,000 in their account on day one, this does not mean that they will be able to trade more than $25,000 because their cash account has not yet been debited. Most cash accounts will include an item detailing "Cash available for trading" which will net out any unsettled business transacted. For example, if someone has a cash account balance of $25,000 on day one, and on the same day they purchase $10,000 worth of shares, then pending settlement in their cash account they will only have $15,000 "Cash available for trading". Similarly, if someone has a cash balance of $25,000 on day one, and on the same day they "day trade", purchasing $15,000 and selling $10,000 worth of shares, then they will have the net of $20,000 "Cash available for trading" ($20,000 = $25,000 - $15,000 + $10,000). If by "prop account" you mean an account where someone gives discretion to a broker to trade on their behalf, then the issues of accounting will be the least of their worries. They will need to be worried about not being fleeced out of their hard earned savings by someone far more interested in lining their own pockets than making money for them.

user_query: What are the differences among all these different versions of Vivendi?
alpaca-7b_response: The main difference between all these different versions of Vivendi is their listing on a stock exchange. Vivendi is listed on the Paris stock exchange, VivEF is listed on the OTC Other Exchange, and VIVHY is listed on the OTC:Pink Sheets. A dual-listed company is a corporate structure in which two corporations function as a single operating business through a legal equalization agreement, but retain separate legal identities and stock exchange listings. Pretty much all DLCs are cross-border, and have tax advantages for the corporations and their stockholders. When a DLC is created, in essence two companies are created and have two separate bodies of shareholders, but they agree to share all the risks and rewards of the ownership of all their operating businesses in a fixed proportion, laid out in a contract called an "equalization agreement". The shares of a DLC parents have claim to the exact same underlying cash flows. So in theory the stock prices of these companies should move exactly the same. However in practice there can be differences between these prices. More info on OTC exchanges can be found here - keep in mind this info is from the company that runs these listings. user_query: Why are big companies like Apple or Google not included in the Dow Jones Industrial Average (DJIA) index?
alpaca-7b_response:
The Dow Jones Industrial Average (DJIA) is a Price-weighted index. This means that the index is calculated by adding up the prices of the constituent stocks and dividing by a constant, the "Dow divisor". This has the curious effect of giving a member of the index influence proportional to its share price. If a stock costing $100 per share goes up by 1%, that will change the index by 10 times as much as if a stock costing $10 per share goes up by the same 1%. 
Apple was in the same boat, with its stock trading at about $700 per share. At that time, Apple split its stock 7:1, and after that its stock price was a little under $100 per share. So, post-split Apple might be a candidate to be included in the Dow the next time they change up the components of the index. 
Since the Dow is fixed at 30 stocks, and since they try to keep a balance between different sectors, this probably wouldn't happen until they drop another technology company from the lineup for some reason. (Correction: Apple is in the DJIA and has been for a little over a year now. Mea culpa.) 
The Dow's price-weighting is unusual as stock indices go. Most indices are weighted by market capitalization. This means the influence of a single company is proportional to its total value. This causes large companies like Apple to have a lot of influence on those indices, but since market capitalization isn't as arbitrary as stock price, most people see that as ok. 
Also, notice that I said "company" and not "stock". When a company has multiple classes of share (as Google does), market-cap-weighted indices include all of the share classes, while the Dow has no provision for such situations, which is another, albeit less important, reason why Google isn't in the Dow. 
Finally, you might be wondering why the Dow uses such an odd weighting in its calculations. The answer is that the Dow averages go back to 1896, when Charles Dow used to calculate the averages by hand. user_query: Thorough Description of Yield to Maturity?
alpaca-7b_response: Yield to maturity (YTM) is the rate of return on a bond that an investor receives for owning it until it matures. It is the discount rate at which the present value of all the cash flows from the bond is equal to the purchase price of the bond. YTM is the rate of return that the investor receives for holding the bond until it matures, and is equal to the coupon rate of the bond plus the current market value of the bond. The yield curve is a graph that plots the yield of bonds of different maturities against their maturity dates. It is a reflection of the current market value of the bonds, and shows the current market value of a bond given its maturity date. The yield curve typically flattens or inverts when creditors become more risk-averse and prefer to keep their money rather than lend it out. This can occur due to a sudden disruption in the market that causes uncertainty about the future, leading to an increase in the demand for cash on hand. The US government yield curve should be looked at with some reservation since there is a very large creditor to the US government that has the ability to loan the government an unlimited amount of funds.

user_query: ESPP strategy - Sell right away or hold?
alpaca-7b_response:
Sell right away or hold?
If you are participating in an ESPP, and there is no required holding period, then selling the shares right away is the best option. This is because you are guaranteed a bonus with minimal risk. However, you should be aware that it may take a while to actually receive the shares at your brokerage, and in the meantime your company may have an earnings report that could cause the share price to drop. If your discount is only 5%, for example, a bad earnings report could easily wipe that out.
The other pro of selling right away is that it simplifies your taxes and you are more likely to invest the money rather than spend it. On the other hand, if you choose to hold the shares, you will have to wait to receive the shares and there is no guarantee that the share price will not drop. Additionally, you will have to account for the ESPP contributions being withheld from your paycheck for months.
Overall, selling the shares right away is the best option if there is no required holding period.
